2. Analgesic
3. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)

Let me explain each of these entities:

1. Aspirin: Aspirin is a chemical compound with the molecular formula C9H8O4. It is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is commonly used to relieve pain, reduce inflammation, and prevent blood clots.
2. Analgesic: Analgesic refers to a drug that relieves pain. Aspirin is an analgesic, as it is used to relieve mild to moderate pain, such as headaches, muscle aches, and menstrual cramps.
3. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): NSAIDs are a class of drugs that are used to relieve pain, reduce inflammation, and lower fever. They work by blocking the production of certain chemicals in the body that cause pain and inflammation. Aspirin is an example of an NSAID.
4. End-stage renal disease (ESRD): ESRD is a condition in which the kidneys are no longer able to filter waste and excess fluids from the blood effectively. It is a serious and often irreversible condition that can lead to complications such as heart disease, anemia, and bone disease.
